author: Thabiso Mochiko
title: Telkom launches wholesale division | Telecoms & Technology
text:
UPBEAT: Telkom Group CEO Sipho Maseko at the Openserve division launch at Turbine Hall in Newtown, where he hailed it as paving the way for the democratisation of broadband. Picture: FREDDY MAVUNDA Related articles Huawei bids for Telkom contract Telkom to rebrand wholesale unit Telkom and Cell C talks stymied by price Telkom won’t pay Cell C asking price, source says In this article JSE-listed companies: Telkom TKG View company tearsheet OPENSERVE would facilitate the entry of new internet service providers, especially black companies, Minister of Telecommunications and Postal Services Siyabonga Cwele said at the Telkom subsidiary’s launch ceremony on Tuesday.
As a stand-alone business unit within Telkom, Openserve would be autonomous and responsible for its own profit and loss account, Telkom said.
Mr Cwele said an open-access environment could create space for black industrialists in the information and communications technology sector.
By restructuring Telkom’s wholesale division as a separate company, it would improve its customer focus and establish clearer lines of accountability.
"This development will accelerate the implementation of the open-access policy that will allow access to critical infrastructure by all licensed operators, reduce barriers to entry to the market and allow infrastructure sharing, thereby reducing duplication of infrastructure," said Mr Cwele.
CEO Sipho Maseko said the market had evolved and Telkom "must welcome a more open-access environment and all the opportunities it offers".
Telkom will play a lead role in government’s national broadband network infrastructure project. The aim is for every citizen to have broadband connection. Telkom sees Openserve paving the way for the democratisation of broadband.
"I personally envisage a South Africa where, like water and electricity, broadband should be within everyone’s reach. It should be open to access," said Mr Maseko.
BMI-TechKnowledge MD Denis Smit said this was long overdue, but that the devil was in the detail as to what extent Openserve would be able to make independent and transparent decisions on strategy and pricing. This could, however, open up a broader consolidation, possibly in the fixed-line wholesale industry and movement towards some form of national broadband network, he said.
But this would take some time to evolve.
The decision to spin off the wholesale business into a stand-alone unit comes three years after the group agreed with the Competition Commission — which found it guilty of anticompetitive behaviour — to implement a functional separation of the wholesale and retail businesses. Such a decision was meant to enable management to be transparent about its pricing to its clients, especially internet service providers.
But Telkom says that unlike its international counterparts, the spinoff was not forced by the regulators. UK’s BT created a separate wholesale business called Openreach about 10 years ago, to house the infrastructure division of BT Group. This came after an agreement between BT and UK regulator Ofcom to ensure rivals got equal access to the operator’s network.
